american_14_tobacco_seed.name: American 14 Tobacco
american_14_tobacco_seed.short_descr: The American 14 Tobacco is Bright Leaf tobacco variety that is imported from Ukraine that will produce 30 leaves per plant. This variety is a tall plant reaching 6' or more in height and is drought tolerant and sunburn resistant. Each American 14 leaf can reach 30" long and 15" wide.
american_14_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
american_14_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
american_14_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
american_14_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
american_14_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
american_14_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

american_572_tobacco_seed.name: American 572 Tobacco
american_572_tobacco_seed.short_descr: American 572 is a tall plant with an aromatic high grade leaf. Excellent for air drying or flu curing. Considered one of the best varieties of Americana.

In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.

Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.

american_572_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

aroma_2_organic_basil_seeds.name: Aroma 2 Organic Basil
aroma_2_organic_basil_seeds.short_descr:
The Aroma 2 Basil produces beautiful glossy, dark green leaves with a strong flavor that is definitely many chefs favorite! This Genovese type of basil has 3" leaves that are slow to bolt.
          
           Certified Organic
          
          .
          
           Learn more about our organic seeds.

big_gem_tobacco_seeds.name: Big Gem Tobacco
big_gem_tobacco_seeds.short_descr: The Big Gem Tobacco is an heirloom Bright Leaf variety that has a great production of over 25 large, bright green leaves per plant. This tobacco variety reaches 5.5' or more in height and each leaf can reach 30" long and 18" wide. The Big Gem is drought tolerant and sunburn resistant.
big_gem_tobacco_seeds.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
big_gem_tobacco_seeds.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.

big_gem_tobacco_seeds.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.

black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.name: Black Sea Samson Tobacco
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Black Sea Samsun originated in the Samsun region of Turkey near the Black Sea. It's prized for rich flavor and aroma, but yet mild to smoke. It grows 4'-5' in height and matures in 65-70 days, and is often sun cured. An excellent blend for cigarettes or pipes, or on its own.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
black_sea_samson_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

bouquet_dill_seed.name: Bouquet Dill
bouquet_dill_seed.short_descr: The Bouquet Dill is an early maturing dill variety with dark feathered green leaves that produces an intoxicating, tangy aroma. The Bouquet is easy to grow and is popular for its flavor and uniform foliage. It can be used to enhance salads, soups and more. Along with its amazing culinary properties, the Bouquet is also perfect for filling in bouquets and cut flowers.
bouquet_dill_seed.before_planting: Dill grows best sown directly into the garden in the early spring after the last frost. To ensure a continuous harvest, plant dill seeds every 10 days up until the early summer. Dill also can be planted in containers, like most herbs, but a deep pot should be used to accommodate for the herb’s deep roots.
bouquet_dill_seed.planting: Plant seeds ¼ inch deep and 18 inches apart.
bouquet_dill_seed.watering: Water regularly. Be careful not to over-water and allow the soil to go dry between watering
bouquet_dill_seed.fertilizer: Similar to most herbs dill does not require fertilizing to grow. In the late spring, a light feeding of a 5-10-5 fertilizer will encourage the dill to grow without being overbearing. If dill is grown in a container, use a liquid fertilizer but only use half of the label’s recommended strength. Fertilize container dill every four to six weeks.
bouquet_dill_seed.days_to_maturity: Dill is ready to harvest any time before its yellow, umbrella-like flowers begin to open. (See each variety for days to maturity)
bouquet_dill_seed.harvesting: Once dill is ready to harvest, you can snip individual stems or pull up the entire plant. To save the dill seeds, cut the dill four inches below the flower head once seeds begin to turn brown. Hang the clippings upside
bouquet_dill_seed.tips: Since dill can grow so tall, shelter it from wind or add a stake to the stem to support the plant as it grows higher.

bouquet_organic_dill_seed.name: Bouquet Organic Dill
bouquet_organic_dill_seed.short_descr: The Bouquet Dill is an early maturing dill variety with dark feathered green leaves that produces an intoxicating, tangy aroma. This early flowering favorite is now available in organic seeds! The Bouquet is easy to grow and is popular for its flavor and uniform foliage. It can be used to enhance salads, soups and more. Along with its amazing culinary properties, the Bouquet is also perfect for filling in bouquets and cut flowers.

bouquet_organic_dill_seed.tips: Since dill can grow so tall, shelter it from wind or add a stake to the stem to support the plant as it grows higher.

broadleaf_sage_seed.name: Broadleaf Sage
broadleaf_sage_seed.short_descr: The Broadleaf Sage is grown mainly for seasoning rich meats and sausages, as well as carrots, tomatoes, squash, corn and potatoes. This Sage has fragrant gray-green leaves and spikes of purple flowers.
broadleaf_sage_seed.planting: Plant the seeds or cuttings indoors up to 10 weeks before the last frost. Plant outdoors up to two weeks before the last frost and leave 30 inches between the seeds or cuttings when planting. Sage does well when planted near cabbage, carrots and rosemary, but do not plant sage near cucumbers.
broadleaf_sage_seed.watering: When sage plants are young, water them frequently to prevent them from drying out.
broadleaf_sage_seed.fertilizer: Twice during its growing season, side dress the plant with compost or a compost tea, especially if the plant is grown in a container. This replaces the nutrients in the soil. Sage doesn’t require any other fertilizer.
broadleaf_sage_seed.days_to_maturity: Once the leaves are full size, they are able to be pulled off. (See variety for days to maturity)
broadleaf_sage_seed.harvesting: To harvest individual leaves, pull them off by hand. Entire stems also can be cut, and they should be snipped at their base. Sage can be harvested in its first year but harvest lightly so the plant grows back completely
broadleaf_sage_seed.tips: Each spring, prune back the woody stems. For the best quality of sage, replace the plants every five years as it begins to become woodier the older the plant gets.

burley_21_tobacco_seed.name: Burley 21 Tobacco
burley_21_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Burley 21 is heirloom Burley variety that is a long time favorite of growers. Its history dates back over 200 years. It grows to 6-7 feet and is a reliable producer of large heavy leaf. It does well in a wide range of climates, and matures in 65-70 days. The leaves make a strong full flavored smoke that is commonly used as a blend in cigarettes, cigars and pipe tobaccos.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
burley_21_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

burley_64_tobacco_seed.name: Burley 64 Tobacco
burley_64_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Burley 64 is a columnar formed plant growing to 6' in height, and reaches maturity in about 65 days. It is a white stemmed burley with large light green leaves that turn bright yellow as they ripen. It gives good yields with very little suckering, and cures easily, either stalk hung or primed. Burley 64 is resistant to black root rot, tobacco mosaic virus, fusarium wilt, and black shank.
burley_64_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
burley_64_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.

Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
burley_64_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
burley_64_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

burley_9_tobacco_seed.name: Burley 9 Tobacco
burley_9_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Burley 9 is a   high-yielding mid-season variety for air curing and drying.  Leaves are light green, averaging 16" wide by 24" long. The leaves turn yellow as they ripen and dry to a light golden brown. It matures in 65 days. Burley 9 is drought resistant and resistant to disease. Nicotine content of 1.6%
burley_9_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
burley_9_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
burley_9_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
burley_9_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. burley_9_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

candy_stevia_seed.name: Candy Stevia
candy_stevia_seed.short_descr: The Candy Stevia is a delicious natural sugar-free sweetener as its small leaves are 30 times sweeter than regular sugar. Once dried, each Candy plant can yield up to 1/2 pound of sweet leaves. Harvest this Stevia for fresh use or dried and grounded into powder. Stevia by nature has low germination rates. 60% is normal. Place directly on grow medium and lightly water. Needs light to germinate.
candy_stevia_seed.before_planting: The stevia plant is bushy and has high yields. Stevia is a perennial but will die back in a hard winter.
candy_stevia_seed.planting: It is best not to sow stevia directly into the garden. Plant seeds indoors up to 10 weeks before the last frost. Seedlings will emerge in up to 21 days. Replant stevia each year to ensure a good harvest.
candy_stevia_seed.watering: Keep the soil consistently moist, but do not over-water.
candy_stevia_seed.fertilizer: Fertilize the plant regularly. If using store-bought fertilizer, follow the instructions
candy_stevia_seed.days_to_maturity: Harvest the stevia just prior to it flowering. If the stevia plant flowers, it can create an unpleasant flavor in the leaves. (See variety for days to maturity)
candy_stevia_seed.harvesting: Individual leaves can be harvested or entire branches of the stevia plant can be picked at once, but never remove more than one-third of the plant at a time. Stevia leaves can be dried by hanging plucked branches upside down in a dry room with the branches tied together.
candy_stevia_seed.tips: Stevia leaves will be sweetest during an autumn harvest, when the temperatures are cooler.

carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.name: Carnival Mix Hollyhock
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.short_descr: Carnival Mix comes in 4 vibrant shades, with big semi- to fully-double flowers that arise all along tall, sturdy stalks beginning just 4 months from sowing. An annual Summer Carnival Hollyhock is a long-blooming, very colorful series so garden-worthy that it received an AAS Award. Tall and stately, it blooms all summer for a rich display of big powderpuff blossoms in every shade of pink, rose, red, and yellow.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.before_planting: Direct sow hollyhock seeds outdoors a week before the last frost date. However, if you are planting from seedlings, wait until two or three weeks after the last frost to transplant them outdoors.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.planting: Plant seeds only 1/4 inch deep and space them at least two feet apart.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.watering: Water regularly to keep the soil moist.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.fertilizer: Hollyhocks do not require a lot of added nutrition, but some extra fertilizer or compost may aid in growth a bit.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.days_to_maturity: Hollyhocks will bloom all summer long, however have a short blooming period.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.harvesting: When cutting hollyhock stems to add to a bouquet, the flowers will stay fresh longer if you cauterize the bottom of the stem.
carnival_mix_hollyhock_seeds.tips: Rust is a common problem attacking hollyhocks. To prevent this issue, be sure to water from below, treat with fungicide and make sure the plant has good air circulation.

chalk_pot_herb_kits.name: Chalk Pot Herb Kits
chalk_pot_herb_kits.short_descr: Everything you need to grow a personalized herb kit at any time of the year! The chalk pot herb kit comes with three pots, trays, your choice of 3 herb varieties, soil, and chalk. Comes with 5 herb packets (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley). This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family. Hand painted with chalk board paint. Pot Dimensions: 3.5"x 3.5"x 3.5". Entire Kit Dimensions: 12"x 12" x 3.5"

cherry_red_tobacco_seed.name: Cherry Red Tobacco
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.short_descr: The Cherry Red Tobacco plant is a cigarette and cigar tobacco that is also a great ornamental herb that produces big, bright yellow-green leaves. This Bright Leaf variety is a heavy producing tobacco plant that can grow to be over 7 feet tall. The Cherry Red plant yields over 25 big leaves per plant that are 24" long and 15" wide.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
cherry_red_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

cinnamon_basil_seeds.name: Cinnamon Basil
cinnamon_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Cinnamon Basil is most widely known for its beautiful cut flower use, but its leaves have a spicy cinnamon-like flavor! This variety has strong violet stems and veining with lavender flowers, that give off a great scent in many bouquets.

common_anise_seeds.name: Common Anise
common_anise_seeds.short_descr: Anise is an annual/biennial herb that produces little, dainty white flowers and seed that has a refreshing licorice flavor. The small 1.5-2 feet tall plants have feather like green leaflets that are great for making aromatic tea. Anise seed produced from the plants can be used whole or ground in doughs or fillings of baked goods or brewed to make a delicate licorice-flavored tea.

common_borage_seed.name: Common Borage
common_borage_seed.short_descr: Borage is a mounded plant that produces beautiful blue flowers that are great for using as a garnish for different dishes or drinks. This large variety is a self seeding annual that bears hundreds of small edible flowers, mostly blue and some pink, over a long harvest. Borage has a mild cucumber flavor that is great for salads and garnishes. Medicinal: Seed oil is a rich source of gamma-linolenic acid.
common_borage_seed.before_planting: If planting in a garden, plant borage near strawberries as this will attract bees to the
common_borage_seed.planting: Sow borage seeds directly into the garden after all danger of frost has passed. Plant seeds ¼ to ½ inch deep in rows set 12 inches apart in an area that receives full sun. If starting seeds indoors, plant three to four weeks before the last frost date. To ensure a long harvest season, sow seeds every four weeks.
common_borage_seed.watering: Water borage often to prevent the plant from drying out, but be careful not to let the soil become soggy.
common_borage_seed.fertilizer: Although borage doesn’t require much fertilizer other than amending the soil with compost prior to planting, the plant itself can be used as a fertilizer or a cover crop.
common_borage_seed.days_to_maturity: Pick the flowers before they have fully bloomed. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_borage_seed.harvesting: Once borage matures, harvest the leaves and flowers as needed. Remove the leaves and flowers from the plant with your fingers or with scissors. The plant leaves do not dry well, so use them fresh.
common_borage_seed.tips: Plant borage near strawberries to bring bees to the garden. It is also said that the plant enhances the flavor of tomatoes if planted near each other.

common_caraway_seeds.name: Common Caraway
common_caraway_seeds.short_descr: Caraway is a biennial herb that produces smooth, finely cut green leaves with little delicate and fragrant white flowers. This furrowed stem plant produces edible flowers and roots. Caraway has a delicious unique flavor that is great to use in baking and preserving.

common_catnip_seed.name: Common Catnip
common_catnip_seed.short_descr:
Catnip is a very fragrant herb that is great for making aromatic teas, as well as giving it to your cats as a treat! This vigorous plant is not only great for playing with a cat, but is also known for having medicinal properties for getting rid of the cold and flu.
          
           Organic seed available.
common_catnip_seed.before_planting: Catnip can be planted from seed or transplanted into the herb bed, but if planting from seed there are certain steps to take to ensure germination. Catnip seeds are tough and need to be stratified, which means they need to be slightly damaged before they will sprout. To stratify a catnip seed, freeze the seeds overnight and then leave the seeds to soak in water for 24 hours.
common_catnip_seed.planting: After you have stratified the seeds, you can plant them indoors or outdoors. If planting outdoors, plant in rows after the last chance of frost. Catnip seeds can be planted in the spring or in the fall.
common_catnip_seed.watering: Water every other week unless in a drought, water once every week.
common_catnip_seed.fertilizer: Catnip grows very quickly and does not require fertilizer. Fertilizing catnip can actually damage the potency of its smell and flavor.
common_catnip_seed.days_to_maturity: Catnip leaves can be plucked at any point during their growing season and flowers should be picked just after they open. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_catnip_seed.harvesting: Pinch off individual leaves and flower blooms or cut entire stems depending on usage. Collect seeds from the flowers to replant if desired, but the catnip will reseed itself in the same spot and return each year.
common_catnip_seed.tips: Catnip can become invasive, and to prevent it from reseeding itself, remove the flowers prior to them going to seed.

common_chamomile_seeds.name: Common Chamomile
common_chamomile_seeds.short_descr: Chamomile is an herb that produces an abundance of small, fragrant daisy-like white flowers that are used in making teas and perfumes. This herb is used to aid in digestion and act as a gentle sleep inducer. You can also use its flowers to garnish desserts or drinks.

common_chive_seeds.name: Common Chive
common_chive_seeds.short_descr: The Chive is a widely known herb that produces flat, solid leaves with a wonderfully pungent flavor that is similar to onions. This plant can grows as high as 1.5' feet and 12" inches wide.
common_chive_seeds.before_planting: Chives can be planted from seed or from divisions. Begin chives indoors eight weeks before the last frost. Transplant chives to the garden when the sprouts reach 6 inches in height.
common_chive_seeds.planting: If planting from seed, plant the seed ¼ inch deep and water well. Chives can be grown outdoors or indoors near a window. If planting inside, keep the pot in a dark area until the seeds sprout, and then move to a windowsill. If planting seeds directly outside, wait until all dangers of frost have passed.
common_chive_seeds.watering: Water chives consistently and add mulch to retain moisture and deter weeds.
common_chive_seeds.fertilizer: Prior to planting the chives, mix 4 to 6 inches of organic compost into the soil and apply 2 to 3 tablespoons of an all-purpose fertilizer, 16-16-8, per square foot of planting area. If you frequently harvest the chives, fertilize every other week with plant food or fish emulsion.
common_chive_seeds.days_to_maturity: Chives are ready to harvest as soon as the leaves are long enough to clip and use in the kitchen. Chives are ready to harvest typically 60 days after planting the seeds.
common_chive_seeds.harvesting: Cut the chives from the outside of the clump, leave a half-inch of stem. To encourage more leaves on the chive plant, pinch off the flower bud.
common_chive_seeds.tips: Chives are perennial plants, and they are more productive if frequently divided. Every three years, divide the plants in the spring.

common_cilantro_seeds.name: Common Cilantro
common_cilantro_seeds.short_descr: The highly aromatic, rich and spicy Cilantro adds the perfect flavor to any cuisine! This plant is ideal for harvesting both the cilantro leaves and coriander seeds.The unique flavor of this cilantro is bold and bright with a touch of citrus undertones. Cilantro is the perfect herb for a patio container or herb kit in a window sill, sow every ten days for a continuous harvest.
common_cilantro_seeds.before_planting: Prior to planting the seeds, you must prepare them so they will be able to germinate. Coriander seeds are actually two seeds encased in a husk. Crush the husk gently by holding the two seeds together and then soak the seeds in water for 24 to 48 hours. Remove the seeds from the water and allow them to dry prior to planting.
common_cilantro_seeds.planting: Cilantro can be started indoors or outdoors. Plant the seeds ¼ inch deep. To transplant a cilantro plant
common_cilantro_seeds.watering: Water regularly, but be careful not to over-water the plant as it could create yellow leaves. To prevent leaf spot, make sure the plant is in well-drained soil.
common_cilantro_seeds.fertilizer: During its first few weeks of life, cilantro grows well if a water-soluble fertilizer is applied. Fertilize with a
common_cilantro_seeds.days_to_maturity: Cilantro is ready to harvest within 45 days.
common_cilantro_seeds.harvesting: Cut the upper new leaves to harvest. Unlike other herbs, cilantro is rarely frozen and used later in cooking as it loses almost all of its scent and flavor if not fresh.
common_cilantro_seeds.tips: Cilantro likes full sun, but in hotter climates, partial shade will be tolerated as the plant bolts in warm weather.

common_cumin_seeds.name: Common Cumin
common_cumin_seeds.short_descr: The beautiful blush, pink flowers of the wonderfully fragrant Cumin plants are used to flavor many popular East Indian dishes! The beautiful foliage has a very aromatic smell that is similar to dill. This herb's young leaves mix very well into salads. Cumin grows best in warmer climates, but will produce seeds in cooler northern climates if started early enough.
common_cumin_seeds.before_planting: Cumin has a longer growing season, so begin indoors four weeks before the last spring frost.
common_cumin_seeds.planting: Plant seeds ¼ inch deep and keep the soil moist until the seeds germinate. Once the minimum temperatures outside reach at least 60 degrees Fahrenheit, transplant the cumin outdoors. If beginning cumin outdoors, plant one or two weeks after the last frost date. Plant a group of four seeds every 4 to 8 inches. Although cumin can be planted early indoors to get a head start on the growing season since it takes a long time to grow, the plant is difficult to transplant and if grown in warmer climates, cumin should be directly sown outdoors.
common_cumin_seeds.watering: Be careful not to over-water cumin plants, and let the soil get almost dry before watering again. Cumin can be susceptible to root rot if it is watered too much, though cumin grown in a container needs to be watered more often as they dry out quicker than those planted in the ground.
common_cumin_seeds.fertilizer: Fertilize cumin with a natural compost tea during its growing season and avoid fertilizers with high nitrogen.
common_cumin_seeds.days_to_maturity: Cumin has a longer growing season than most herbs, taking 120 days to mature.
common_cumin_seeds.harvesting: Cut the entire stem and then hang upside down in a paper bag or over a container that will catch the seeds as they fall out. Harvest the leaves whenever they are large enough to be used in a salad. Cumin seeds
common_cumin_seeds.tips: Plant cumin near crops that attract caterpillars or aphids to help control those pests. Although cumin can control pests in the garden, it also grows well in containers like most herbs.

common_hyssop_seeds.name: Common Hyssop
common_hyssop_seeds.short_descr: Hyssop is a popular ornamental herb in the mint family that is great for attracting bees and other beneficial insects to the garden. This herb produces bright blue to violet flowers that are used to make a soothing tea. You can harvest the flowers in midsummer and hang them upside down under shade to dry.
common_hyssop_seeds.before_planting: Sow the hyssop seeds indoors eight to 10 weeks before the last frost of the season.
common_hyssop_seeds.planting: Transplant the seedlings into the garden after the last frost and space the plants about 6 to 12 inches apart.
common_hyssop_seeds.watering: Provide 1 inch of water once or twice weekly.
common_hyssop_seeds.fertilizer: Prior to transplanting the seedlings to the garden, amend the soil with compost or organic material like aged animal manure.
common_hyssop_seeds.days_to_maturity: Hyssop will reach its maturity in 75 to 85 days from planting.
common_hyssop_seeds.harvesting: Cut in the morning once the dew has dried. Then, hang upside down in a dark and well-ventilated area.
common_hyssop_seeds.tips: Hyssop needs to be pruned, so if you have a well-established plant, trim it back in the early spring.

common_lemon_balm_seeds.name: Common Lemon Balm
common_lemon_balm_seeds.short_descr: Lemon Balm is a wonderfully aromatic herb that is used for flavorings and teas! This variety can grow up to 2 feet-tall. Lemon Balm will bloom beautiful fragrant white flowers that are great for attracting bees to your garden for pollination.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.before_planting: Plant lemon balm after all dangers of frost has passed. The herb can be started indoors six to eight weeks before the last frost and then transplanted into the garden.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.planting: If planting from seed, barely cover the seeds with soil. When transplanting lemon balm into the garden, choose a spot where the plant will be protected from the harsh midday sun. If planting seeds directly into the garden, loosen the soil with a rake prior to planting. Plant the seeds at least 12 inches apart in rows set 2 feet apart.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.watering: Once the lemon balm has sprouted, continue to water regularly.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.fertilizer: It is suggested that gardeners don’t fertilize lemon balm very much, as too much fertilizer can cause the herb’s scent to fade. However, since lemon balm is harvested for its leaves, a little bit of fertilizer can encourage more growth. Add a continuous-release fertilizer at the rate the label recommends. You can also amend the soil with compost cottonseed meal or bloodmeal.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.days_to_maturity: Lemon balm is ready to harvest once its leaves reach the desired size. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_lemon_balm_seeds.harvesting: Use snips to cut off portions of the lemon balm to use. Leaves can be harvested throughout the summer.
common_lemon_balm_seeds.tips: Lemon balm responds well to cutting back, so cut the plant back at the end of each season and it will grow back bushier than before.

common_lemongrass_seed.name: Common Lemongrass
common_lemongrass_seed.short_descr: The deliciously fresh, citrus lemon flavor of the Lemongrass is a very popular herb variety for its many different culinary uses. This lemongrass variety can be used to flavor teas, beverages, soups, and many other dishes. The lemongrass plant can reach up to 6 feet tall.
common_lemongrass_seed.before_planting: Lemongrass grows best in the summer and does well in heat, as it is a tropical plant. It grows best in a container and prefers full sun.
common_lemongrass_seed.planting: Plant lemongrass seeds ¼ inch deep and 1 inch apart and begin them inside up to three weeks before the last frost date. If planting inside, plant the lemongrass in seedling trays that can be covered so the seeds have a warm, moist environment to germinate. Once the seedlings appear, remove the plastic covering and transplant them outdoors to a location in full sun.
common_lemongrass_seed.watering: Throughout lemongrass’s growing period, keep its soil moist by watering two to three times a week.
common_lemongrass_seed.fertilizer: Feed lemongrass with a high-nitrogen fertilizer when you transplant it outdoors, such as alfalfa meal or blood meal. To fertilize, mix ½ cup of the fertilizer into the soil before transplanting the lemongrass seedlings. After transplanting, fertilize lemongrass every couple of weeks during its growing season with a liquid plant food or fish emulsion.
common_lemongrass_seed.days_to_maturity: Lemongrass is ready to harvest when the stalks are at least ½ inch thick, dark green and at least 18 inches tall. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_lemongrass_seed.harvesting: Harvest lemongrass by snipping the entire stalk at its base. When harvesting lemongrass, be sure to wear gloves as the stalks can irritate the skin. At the end of its growing season, cut lemongrass plants back to only 6 inches tall and reduce watering and discontinue fertilizing.
common_lemongrass_seed.tips: Sometimes, lemongrass can suffer from leaf blight, which is when the lemongrass leaves turn brown and begin to wilt. Remove the infected leaves and spray the plant with copper sulfate, which is a fungicide that is safe for edible plants.

common_lovage_seeds.name: Common Lovage
common_lovage_seeds.short_descr: Lovage is a popular culinary herb that produces fine, dark green leaves that have an aroma and taste that is similar to celery. Its leaves can be used in salads, soups as well as added to poultry dishes. The Lovage's roots and stems are also edible. The yellow flowers that this herb produces in June to July attract beneficial insects such as bees.
common_lovage_seeds.before_planting: Direct sow seeds five to six weeks before the last frost date.
common_lovage_seeds.planting: Sow the seeds on the surface of the soil and dust a light covering of sand over.
common_lovage_seeds.days_to_maturity: Lovage will begin to bloom in the early summer and continue blooming through late summer.
common_lovage_seeds.harvesting: All parts of the lovage herb are harvestable. Its leaves can be added to salads, roots can be dug up after the season is over to be used as a vegetable and stems can replace celery.
common_lovage_seeds.tips: Lovage is a good companion plant for potatoes and other root vegetables.

common_organic_catnip_seed.name: Common Organic Catnip
common_organic_catnip_seed.short_descr:
Catnip is a very fragrant herb that is great for making aromatic teas, as well as giving it to your cats as a treat! This vigorous plant is not only great for playing with a cat, but is also known for having medicinal properties for getting rid of the cold and flu.
          
           Conventional seed available.
common_organic_catnip_seed.before_planting: Catnip can be planted from seed or transplanted into the herb bed, but if planting from seed there are certain steps to take to ensure germination. Catnip seeds are tough and need to be stratified, which means they need to be slightly damaged before they will sprout. To stratify a catnip seed, freeze the seeds overnight and then leave the seeds to soak in water for 24 hours.
common_organic_catnip_seed.planting: After you have stratified the seeds, you can plant them indoors or outdoors. If planting outdoors, plant in rows after the last chance of frost. Catnip seeds can be planted in the spring or in the fall.
common_organic_catnip_seed.watering: Water every other week unless in a drought, water once every week.
common_organic_catnip_seed.fertilizer: Catnip grows very quickly and does not require fertilizer. Fertilizing catnip can actually damage the potency of its smell and flavor.
common_organic_catnip_seed.days_to_maturity: Catnip leaves can be plucked at any point during their growing season and flowers should be picked just after they open. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_organic_catnip_seed.harvesting: Pinch off individual leaves and flower blooms or cut entire stems depending on usage. Collect seeds from the flowers to replant if desired, but the catnip will reseed itself in the same spot and return each year.
common_organic_catnip_seed.tips: Catnip can become invasive, and to prevent it from reseeding itself, remove the flowers prior to them going to seed.

common_organic_cilantro_seeds.name: Common Organic Cilantro
common_organic_cilantro_seeds.short_descr: The highly aromatic, rich and spicy Cilantro adds the perfect flavor to any cuisine! This popular herb now also comes in organic seeds. This plant can be harvested for both the cilantro leaves and coriander seeds. The unique flavor of this cilantro is bold and bright with a touch of citrus undertones. Cilantro is the perfect herb for a patio container or herb kit in a window sill, sow every ten days for a continuous harvest.

common_rosemary_seed.name: Common Rosemary
common_rosemary_seed.short_descr: Rosemary is a very popular herb for its many uses, such as in potpourris and aromatherapy as well as flavoring many dishes! Start the seeds early indoors for a better harvest. Rosemary should be set outside early and will tolerate light frost.
common_rosemary_seed.before_planting: When beginning rosemary from seed, understand it is a slow-to-grow, woody perennial that will not be ready to harvest its first year. Soak seeds up to six hours in water to encourage the germination process.
common_rosemary_seed.planting: Sow seeds indoors in mid-February to April and transplant or direct sow into the garden in May. When planting seeds, barely cover them with a seed starting mix and apply bottom heat. Keep rosemary in its own pot during its first year of growth, but you can transplant it to the garden the following spring.
common_rosemary_seed.watering: Keep rosemary watered during hot weather and apply mulch around the plant once winter approaches.
common_rosemary_seed.fertilizer: To correctly fertilize rosemary, fertilize with weekly applications of a high-nitrogen formula during the spring months but withhold fertilizer during the fall and winter. Sprinkle the organic matter around the base of the plant and cultivate it into the soil. Rosemary also can be harvested with a continuous release fertilizer.
common_rosemary_seed.days_to_maturity: Rosemary is a slow-to-grow perennial that may take up to a year to be ready to harvest. (See variety for days to harvest)
common_rosemary_seed.harvesting: To harvest rosemary, pull individual leaves off the plant or cut entire stems. Rosemary is also often used dried. To dry rosemary, hang bunches of the plant upside down on a rack. Strip the leaves from the stems once the stems are dry.
common_rosemary_seed.tips: Grow rosemary near beans, Brassicas or carrots.

common_rue_seed.name: Common Rue
common_rue_seed.short_descr: Rue produces attractive blue-green and pungently bitter foliage that have great medicinal uses as being an antispasmodic. This hardy perennial is an ornamental plant is lovely in the garden.
common_rue_seed.before_planting: Once temperatures reach 70 degrees on average, it is time to plant rue. Find a barren area of the garden in full sun with well-draining soil and turn the soil with a shovel. Rake it smooth.
common_rue_seed.planting: Scatter rue seeds across the surface of the soil and then gently press the seeds into the soil with your
common_rue_seed.watering: Rue is drought tolerant so it rarely needs watered. Add a mulch of hay or cut up leaves around the plants to control weeds and retain water. Water deeply every three weeks. Over-watering can cause root rot.
common_rue_seed.fertilizer: Rue doesn’t require amendments to the soil prior to planting as it is a very hardy plant. In the early spring, once new growth begins, apply a complete fertilizer with equal portions of nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium. Use a granular fertilizer and apply 2 pounds of fertilizer per each 1,000 feet of soil.
common_rue_seed.days_to_maturity: Rue is ready to be harvested before its flowers are about to bloom. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_rue_seed.harvesting: Take care when harvesting rue, as its sap can irritate the skin and leave rashes. Once harvested, rue can be used as an insect repellent.
common_rue_seed.tips: During its growing season, remove and discard any branches or leaves that become a different color or wilt. In the fall, cover the plants with 24 inches of protective mulch, such as leaves. Although the plant is very hardy, it does require winter protection. In the spring, cut back the branches, as this encourages new growth.

common_tansy_seed.name: Common Tansy
common_tansy_seed.short_descr: Tansy is a beautiful yellow blooming herb that actually can help repel insects and may help deter ants and mice in the garden. This herb works better when its made into a tea and sprayed around the yard. If placed in a compost pile, Tansy will add potassium to it. Tansy will grow to be 2-3 feet in height.
common_tansy_seed.before_planting: Tansy can grow in full sun or partial shade. It does best in fertile, well-drained soil and in an area that has little vegetation already established.
common_tansy_seed.planting: Tansy seeds can be started indoors as early as eight weeks before the last frost if being planted in the spring. If planting in the spring, sow directly into the garden 1/4-inch-deep as soon as the danger of frost has passed. Tansy seeds will germinate in 15 to 30 days.
common_tansy_seed.watering: Tansy plants require little attention and only need to be watered occasionally and during dry periods.
common_tansy_seed.fertilizer: It is best to amend the soil with plenty of compost prior to planting the tansy seeds. Add fertilizer once a month to the plants.
common_tansy_seed.days_to_maturity: Tansy leaves and flowers are ready to be harvested after around 75 days.
common_tansy_seed.harvesting: Harvest both the leaves and flowers during the plant’s flowering period, which is from June to September. Harvest a bunch of tansy leaves and hang indoors to serve as a fly repellent. The leaves and
common_tansy_seed.tips: Tansy is often used as a companion plant in the garden as it repels many pests. The plant also can be harvested and made into a liquid that is then sprayed around the garden. To do this, add dehydrated tansy into steaming water and spray around the garden.

common_tarragon_seed.name: Common Tarragon
common_tarragon_seed.short_descr: The Artemesia dracunculoides, or commonly known as Tarragon, is an aromatic leafy herb that is growing in popularity for its culinary uses. This herb is a tall vigorous garden plant that produces leaves that have a mild flavor, pairing well with fish, chicken and vegetable dishes.
common_tarragon_seed.before_planting: Tarragon grows best in full sun in soil with a pH of 6.5 to 7.5. Because of its great root system, tarragon can thrive in poorer soils.
common_tarragon_seed.planting: Begin tarragon seeds indoors in April and sow four to six seeds per pot in moist, composted potting soil. Once seedlings sprout a few inches, thin them to one seedling per pot. Transplant tarragon seedlings outdoors once the last frost has passed. Upon transplanting them outside, space tarragon plants 18 to 24 inches apart if planting in the garden.
common_tarragon_seed.watering: Tarragon does not require frequent watering unless there is a drought.
common_tarragon_seed.fertilizer: Prior to planting tarragon outdoors or transplanting it, mix 1 to 2 inches of compost into the top 6 inches of soil and add ½ tablespoon of an all-purpose fertilizer per square foot. After planting, there is no need to fertilize as tarragon’s flavor will intensify in low-nutrient soil.
common_tarragon_seed.days_to_maturity: Both the leaves and the flowers of tarragon can be harvested and are usually ready for harvest in the late summer. (See variety for days to maturity)
common_tarragon_seed.harvesting: Harvest tarragon in the morning and do so by stripping the lower leaves from the stem first.
common_tarragon_seed.tips: Divide the tarragon plants every three to five years to ensure its best growth.

creeping_thyme_seeds.name: Creeping Thyme
creeping_thyme_seeds.short_descr: The Creeping Thyme is a mat-forming evergreen plant that produces small purple spikes and makes a beautiful ground cover! This "walk on" hardy perennial not only adds a beautiful pop of color to the garden, but it also gives off a wonderful fragrance that is perfect in a bouquet.
creeping_thyme_seeds.before_planting: Thyme grows very slowly from seed and after planting, germination can take up to 28 days.
creeping_thyme_seeds.planting: If planting from seed, begin thyme indoors and scatter the seeds on top of the soil and do not cover them or only cover them lightly. If growing thyme in containers, repot the thyme every season, as its roots may begin to grow out the bottom of the container.
creeping_thyme_seeds.watering: Thyme doesn’t require much care. Allow soil to completely dry in between watering.
creeping_thyme_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add a continuous-release fertilizer to the soil. Add the fertilizer again each spring. Other fertilization options include fertilizing thyme with fish emulsion or liquid seaweed every two weeks but dilute the fertilizer by half.
creeping_thyme_seeds.days_to_maturity: Harvest thyme before its flowers open which should be after 85 days.
creeping_thyme_seeds.harvesting: Harvest by cutting the plant 2 inches from the ground. After the first cut is made, more growth will begin to develop but do not harvest this second growth as the new growth increases the plant’s hardiness over
creeping_thyme_seeds.tips: Stop harvest a month before the first fall frost to ensure the plants are strong enough for the winter. After harvesting, lay the thyme in single layers on newspaper in the shade. Once dry, rub the leaves and they will separate easily from the stems.

cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.name: Cuban Criollo 98 Tobacco
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Cuban Criollo 98 is one of the most valued strains for Cuban cigars. It originated from a crossing between the varieties ' Havana 92' and `Habana P.R'. Cultivated in the sun it produces from 14 to 16 useful leaves per plant and makes an excellent binder. It reaches an average height of 6 feet. Leaves average 24 inches in length and 12 inches wide. It is resistant to the Blue Mold, the Blackish Paw and the Tobacco Mosaic Virus and moderately resistant to the Environmental Necrosis.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
cuban_criollo_98_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

culinary_blend_basil_seeds.name: Culinary Blend Basil
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Culinary Blend is the perfect basil blend for a kitchen herb garden, as it offers both sweet and savory types of basil. This delicious blend contains: Genovese, Corsican, Lemon and Lime basil. Enjoy this mix for drying, freezing or using fresh!
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
culinary_blend_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

dark_opal_basil_seeds.name: Dark Opal Basil
dark_opal_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Dark Opal Basil is a unique, wonderfully delicious tasting, purple colored basil that is popular for micro green production! These mostly purple plants, with 20% variegated or green plants, make for a beautiful color combo. The Dark Opal's leaves average at 1 1/2-3" at full size.

dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.name: Dominican Republic Olor Tobacco
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.short_descr:
Olor produces a leaf of very good quality. The plant grows to 6' with little to no suckering. The leaves are light green, sharply pointed and average 14" wide and 20" to 22" long, becoming yellow as they ripen. It reaches maturity and begins blooming in approximately 60 days. 

*  "The Dominican Republic is the leading country worldwide when it comes to tobacco cultivation. Its cigars are the most popular in the United States, one of the most tobacco-loving countries in the world. They have recently been able to overtake their direct rival, the Havana cigar, as the world’s most popular tobacco

  According to the International Tobacco Growers’ Association, they have already conquered 60% of the North American tobacco market. At the same time, the whole of Europe as well as most African and Asian countries, including China, are faithful clients of the Dominican tobacco market."
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
dominican_republic_olor_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

dry_erase_herb_kits.name: Dry Erase Herb Kits
dry_erase_herb_kits.short_descr:
Everything you need to grow a custom dry erase herb kit at any time of the year! Comes with 5 herb packets (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley). This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family. Hand painted with dry erase board paint.
			Includes: 3 dry erase pots, trays, soil, marker, and seeds. Pots are made of recycled bamboo husk. Pot dimensions: 3.5"x 3.5"x 3.5". Entire herb kit dimensions: 12"x 3.5"x 3.5".

dukat_dill_seeds.name: Dukat Dill
dukat_dill_seeds.short_descr: The Dukat Dill is a popular, improved dill variety that produces a high amount of its essential oil! This dill's attractive ferny foliage is best when used fresh or dried in dips, salads, soups and sauces - as well as to flavor peas and potatoes.
dukat_dill_seeds.before_planting: Dill grows best sown directly into the garden in the early spring after the last frost. To ensure a continuous harvest, plant dill seeds every 10 days up until the early summer. Dill also can be planted in containers, like most herbs, but a deep pot should be used to accommodate for the herb’s deep roots.
dukat_dill_seeds.planting: Plant seeds ¼ inch deep and 18 inches apart.
dukat_dill_seeds.watering: Water regularly. Be careful not to over-water and allow the soil to go dry between watering
dukat_dill_seeds.fertilizer: Similar to most herbs dill does not require fertilizing to grow. In the late spring, a light feeding of a 5-10-5 fertilizer will encourage the dill to grow without being overbearing. If dill is grown in a container, use a liquid fertilizer but only use half of the label’s recommended strength. Fertilize container dill every four to six weeks.
dukat_dill_seeds.days_to_maturity: Dill is ready to harvest any time before its yellow, umbrella-like flowers begin to open. (See each variety for days to maturity)
dukat_dill_seeds.harvesting: Once dill is ready to harvest, you can snip individual stems or pull up the entire plant. To save the dill seeds, cut the dill four inches below the flower head once seeds begin to turn brown. Hang the clippings upside
dukat_dill_seeds.tips: Since dill can grow so tall, shelter it from wind or add a stake to the stem to support the plant as it grows higher.

english_lavender_seeds.name: English Lavender
english_lavender_seeds.short_descr: The English Lavender is an improved lavender variety that offers 30% more young plants and a 80% minimum germination. This lavender is a popular variety for many bouquets that produces beautiful lilac flowers with lots of ornamental blue-gray leaves.
english_lavender_seeds.before_planting: Lavender should be planted outside after the last spring frost. You can also begin lavender inside and once the plants have their first set of leaves, transplant them to their final spot outdoors. However, if beginning inside, use a vermiculite mix instead of traditional potting mix to allow for better drainage.
english_lavender_seeds.planting: When transplanting, space plants 12 inches apart in rows set 12 inches apart. Lavender also can grow in containers. If growing in a container, use a porous soil and don’t over-water.
english_lavender_seeds.watering: Lavender thrives in hot weather, so be careful not to over-water as sodden soil can damage the plants.
english_lavender_seeds.fertilizer: Lavender plants typically grow best in soil with poor nutrients. Over-fertilizing the plant can cause an excess in leaves and limited fragrant flowers. A more natural way to fertilize lavender is by placing an inch of compost around the plant. Do not fertilize the plant in the fall, as this will encourage new growth that will then be killed by the winter months.
english_lavender_seeds.days_to_maturity: Once the herb begins to bloom, remove the faded flowers to encourage more growth. Lavender is a perennial in some zones, so cut the dead branches back in the spring to prepare for the new season. (See each variety for days to maturity)
english_lavender_seeds.harvesting: If using lavender as a bouquet, harvest it before the buds have fully opened. Partially closed buds will keep their scent and color longer.
english_lavender_seeds.tips: Add sand or limestone gravel to a bed to improve its drainage or plant the lavender in raised beds.

english_thyme_seed.name: English Thyme
english_thyme_seed.short_descr: The English Thyme is a beautiful purple-gray flowering herb that brings out a great flavor when added to different dishes. This herb grows tall and wide and if allowed to flower, will bring butterflies and bees to the garden. English Thyme is commonly used for seasoning either fresh or dried.
english_thyme_seed.before_planting: Thyme grows very slowly from seed and after planting, germination can take up to 28 days.
english_thyme_seed.planting: If planting from seed, begin thyme indoors and scatter the seeds on top of the soil and do not cover them or only cover them lightly. If growing thyme in containers, repot the thyme every season, as its roots may begin to grow out the bottom of the container.
english_thyme_seed.watering: Thyme doesn’t require much care. Allow soil to completely dry in between watering.
english_thyme_seed.fertilizer: Upon planting, add a continuous-release fertilizer to the soil. Add the fertilizer again each spring. Other fertilization options include fertilizing thyme with fish emulsion or liquid seaweed every two weeks but dilute the fertilizer by half.
english_thyme_seed.days_to_maturity: Harvest thyme before its flowers open which should be after 85 days.
english_thyme_seed.harvesting: Harvest by cutting the plant 2 inches from the ground. After the first cut is made, more growth will begin to develop but do not harvest this second growth as the new growth increases the plant’s hardiness over
english_thyme_seed.tips: Stop harvest a month before the first fall frost to ensure the plants are strong enough for the winter. After harvesting, lay the thyme in single layers on newspaper in the shade. Once dry, rub the leaves and they will separate easily from the stems.

evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.name: Evergreen Organic Parsley
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.short_descr:
The Evergreen Parsley is a dark green curly variety with an excellent flavor, fresh or dried, and is an All-American Selection winner for a reason! This Parsley is frost resistant and grows vigorously. Evergreen is perfect for adding to soups, salads or even as a garnish.
          
           Certified Organic
          
          .
          
           Learn more about our organic seeds.
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.before_planting: Like most herbs, parsley can be grown indoors, in a container or in the garden. To encourage parsley to have a better germination, soak the seeds in water overnight.
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.planting: Parsley seeds can be sown directly into the garden as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring, but they also can be started indoors six weeks before moving out to the garden since parsley has a slow germination
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.watering: Parsley requires little maintenance and only needs watering once per week.
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.fertilizer: If growing parsley in the ground, parsley does best with a single application of fertilizer halfway through the growing season with a 5-10-5 fertilizer. Growing parsley in pots calls for more fertilizer, so apply fertilizer every six weeks for pots indoors and every four weeks if grown in pots outdoors.
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.days_to_maturity: Once parsley leaves begin to curl or when the leaves have three separate segments, they are ready to harvest. (See each variety for days to harvest)
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.harvesting: Pick parsley leaves early in the morning as that is when the herb’s scent is the strongest. To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.
evergreen_organic_parsley_seed.tips: Parsley is mostly disease resistant, though it can be a victim to aphids.

florence_fennel_seed.name: Florence Fennel
florence_fennel_seed.short_descr: Florences's fresh fennel leaves are a favorite on salads, with eggs, fish and sauces! This fennel has a bulbous stem that can be steamed, grilled or served raw, like celery. When cut, this fennel has a delicate anise aroma. Florence thrives in full sun and mild to cool weather.
florence_fennel_seed.Seed Count: Approximately 64,000 seeds per pound (4,000 seeds per ounce).

forest_green_parsley_seed.name: Forest Green Parsley
forest_green_parsley_seed.short_descr: The Forest Green Parsley is a delicately curled and compact variety that has long stems with dark green, double and tripled curled leaves. This type of parsley does well in containers and inside growing. Use the Forest Green's beautiful and delicious leaves fresh or dried.

forest_green_parsley_seed.watering: Parsley requires little maintenance and only needs watering once per week.

Growing parsley in pots calls for more fertilizer, so apply fertilizer every six weeks for pots indoors and every four weeks if grown in pots outdoors.
forest_green_parsley_seed.days_to_maturity: Once parsley leaves begin to curl or when the leaves have three separate segments, they are ready to harvest. (See each variety for days to harvest)
forest_green_parsley_seed.harvesting: Pick parsley leaves early in the morning as that is when the herb’s scent is the strongest. To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.

french_thyme_seed.name: French Thyme
french_thyme_seed.short_descr: The French Thyme is a popular herb used to add flavor in poultry and fishes dishes as well as salads, stews, sauces and pickles! This Thyme variety produces very aromatic blue-green leaves with pale lavender flowers that will add a pop of beautiful color to any garden or windowsill.

french_thyme_seed.harvesting: Harvest by cutting the plant 2 inches from the ground. After the first cut is made, more growth will begin to develop but do not harvest this second growth as the new growth increases the plant’s hardiness over
french_thyme_seed.tips: Stop harvest a month before the first fall frost to ensure the plants are strong enough for the winter. After harvesting, lay the thyme in single layers on newspaper in the shade. Once dry, rub the leaves and they will separate easily from the stems.

genovese_basil_seeds.name: Genovese Basil
genovese_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Genovese Basil is an old popular heirloom basil variety that has a very strong tangy scent that is favored by many chefs. The 2" long dark green leaves of the Genovese basil are slow to bolt.
genovese_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
genovese_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
genovese_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
genovese_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
genovese_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
genovese_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
genovese_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

giant_of_italy_parsley_seed.name: Giant of Italy Parsley
giant_of_italy_parsley_seed.short_descr: The Giant of Italy Parsley is an attractive and large growing parsley with dark green leaves that are known for being easy to cut! This variety has strong stems, making it one of the best parsleys for fresh market sales. The very high yielding Giant of Italy is a customer favorite for a reason!

To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.
giant_of_italy_parsley_seed.tips: Parsley is mostly disease resistant, though it can be a victim to aphids.

gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.name: Gold Leaf 939 Tobacco
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Gold Leaf 939 is a bright leaf Virginia type tobacco with very good yields of leaf averaging 12" wide by 20" long. It grow 5-6 feet in height with closely spaced leaves and matures in 60 to 65 days. It has excellent uniformity between plants which makes it easy to manage. Suckering is very low. The leaves turn yellow as it ripens, and air cure to a light golden brown.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
gold_leaf_939_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

golden_burley_tobacco_seed.name: Golden Burley Tobacco
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Golden Burley is a medium flavored Burley with excellent curability. The leaves grow up to 30" long by 12" wide, and turn a bright lemon yellow when ripe. Plants grow 5 to 6 feet in height with little to no suckering. Matures in 60-65 days after transplant. Air cures to a light buck skin brown color. The smoke is flavorful, yet mild. Requires less aging time than most Burleys.
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.

In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
golden_burley_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

greek_oregano_seed.name: Greek Oregano
greek_oregano_seed.short_descr: The Greek Oregano is a popular herb with an excellent flavor that is a must for many Italian dishes like fish, pizza, tomato sauce and dressings. This perennial has a stronger and more aromatic fragrance than the common oregano and is known for its culinary and ornamental uses. Enjoy the Greek Oregano's beautiful purple blooms all summer long!
greek_oregano_seed.before_planting: Plant seeds indoor before the last frost date, as early as February. Similar to marjoram, oregano seeds are dust-like and fragile.
greek_oregano_seed.planting: Do not bury them in soil but distribute them evenly across the top of the soil and mist with water. Cover the seed tray with a plastic dome and place in a sunny window. Once the dangers of frost have passed,
greek_oregano_seed.watering: Only water oregano during long dry periods.
greek_oregano_seed.fertilizer: Oregano is a very hardy plant that doesn’t require fertilization. If you choose to fertilize the plant, do so lightly as not to damage it. However, oregano can grow in poor, dry conditions and doesn’t need fertilizer to produce its flavorful leaves.
greek_oregano_seed.days_to_maturity: Once oregano reaches 4 to 6 inches tall, it is ready to harvest. (See each variety for days to harvest)
greek_oregano_seed.harvesting: Harvest by pinching off individual leaves or clipping an entire branch. The leaves can be dried or frozen but store them away from direct light.
greek_oregano_seed.tips: Once plants flower, cut them back to prevent them from growing leggy. After its growing season, cut oregano down to the ground and cover with mulch. If oregano is growing in a container, bring the container indoors to continue growth throughout the winter.

green_ruffles_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Green Ruffles Basil produces large serrated, cut and ruffled dark green leaves that have a great tangy and rich flavor! This basil variety is popular for its culinary uses and is excellent for many tomato based dishes.

green_ruffles_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.

hamburg_rooted_parsley_seed.short_descr: The Hamburg Rooted Parsley is a unique looking, old heirloom variety that is used for both its delicious leaves and roots! This parsley is mostly grown for its large roots that make superb soups and stews, but its leaves are also tasty in sauces or as a garnish.

havana_142_tobacco_seed.name: Havana 142 Tobacco
havana_142_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Havana 142 is classified as a cigar binder but is often used in making chew. Many growers find it makes an excellent cigarette tobacco as well. A columnar plant which grows to a height of 4 feet, it matures in only 55 days. A good choice for areas with short growing seasons. Air cures to a light brown.

havana_142_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
havana_142_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
havana_142_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
havana_142_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

havana_608_tobacco_seed.name: Havana 608 Tobacco
havana_608_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Havana 608 is a cigar filler or binder tobacco. It grows to 6' closely spaced leaves and matures in about 65 days. The leaves are a very bright green and upturned with slightly down turned tips. It holds up well during inclement weather and the pyramidal shape gives it good wind resistance. The leaves turn a light yellow green with yellowing at the edges when ripe. Plants average 20 harvestable leaves per plant, and are 14"-16" in width and 20" long. Air cures to a medium brown.

indoor_herb_kit_garden_gifts.short_descr:
Everything you need to grow a custom herb kit at any time of the year! The indoor herb kit comes with three 100% biodegradable pots and tray stands! Comes with herb seeds (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley), soil, wooden plant markers and planting instructions. This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family.
			Made of rice husks and bamboo scraps, you can expect years of use inside your home. Pot Dimensions: 3.5"x 3.5"x 3.5" Entire Kit Dimensions: 12"x 12" x 3.5"
