italian_plain_leaf_parsley_seeds.harvesting: Pick parsley leaves early in the morning as that is when the herb’s scent is the strongest. To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.
italian_plain_leaf_parsley_seeds.tips: Parsley is mostly disease resistant, though it can be a victim to aphids.

krausa_parsley_seed.name: Krausa Parsley
krausa_parsley_seed.short_descr: The Krausa Parsley is an excellent tripled curled parsley variety with beautiful, heavy-bearing ornamental leaves that are almost too pretty to cut! This parsley variety has dense, attractive dark green leaves on strong stalks. The nice texture of the Krausa Parsley leaves is perfect fresh or dried.
krausa_parsley_seed.before_planting: Like most herbs, parsley can be grown indoors, in a container or in the garden. To encourage parsley to have a better germination, soak the seeds in water overnight.
krausa_parsley_seed.planting: Parsley seeds can be sown directly into the garden as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring, but they also can be started indoors six weeks before moving out to the garden since parsley has a slow germination
krausa_parsley_seed.watering: Parsley requires little maintenance and only needs watering once per week.
krausa_parsley_seed.fertilizer: If growing parsley in the ground, parsley does best with a single application of fertilizer halfway through the growing season with a 5-10-5 fertilizer. Growing parsley in pots calls for more fertilizer, so apply fertilizer every six weeks for pots indoors and every four weeks if grown in pots outdoors.
krausa_parsley_seed.days_to_maturity: Once parsley leaves begin to curl or when the leaves have three separate segments, they are ready to harvest. (See each variety for days to harvest)
krausa_parsley_seed.harvesting: Pick parsley leaves early in the morning as that is when the herb’s scent is the strongest. To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.
krausa_parsley_seed.tips: Parsley is mostly disease resistant, though it can be a victim to aphids.

large_leaf_italian_basil_seeds.name: Large Leaf Italian Basil
large_leaf_italian_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Large Leaf Italian Basil produces large, light green leaves that offers an excellent aroma to any meal, soup or sauce! This variety is our most popular basil plant. The Large Leaf Italian is a prolific plant that produces very large leaves with some that can even cover a slice of bread! This variety is sweeter than the Genovese basil, and produces an attractive, bushy plant with its very popular, aromatic leaves.

large_leaf_organic_basil_seeds.name: Large Leaf Organic Basil
large_leaf_organic_basil_seeds.short_descr:
The Large Leaf Basil gives off a delicious tangy aroma and flavor that is excellent for fresh pesto! This plant variety will grow to be 24-30 inches tall. This fragrant heirloom basil is heat-loving and thrives in full sun. The Large Leaf's shiny dark green leaves can grow up to 4 inches long and is perfect for a home garden or in a windowsill container!
          
           Certified Organic
          
          .
          
           Learn more about our organic seeds.

lemon_basil_seeds.name: Lemon Basil
lemon_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Lemon Basil is a very attractive and deliciously fragrant basil plant that offers such great smelling light green leaves! This variety's small,  beautiful fragrant leaves on its compact plants delightfully combine the flavors of lemon and basil. The Lemon Basil is an excellent choice for fresh or dried use.
lemon_basil_seeds.Seed Count: Approximately 2,560 seeds per pound (160 seeds per ounce).

lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.name: Lettuce Leaf Basil
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Lettuce Leaf Basil has very large, hand sized, creased leaves that resembles a lettuce leaf, but has a great traditional basil flavor! This great production basil variety is favored among farmers and people who like a lot of basil due to its yields produces lots of foliage.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
lettuce_leaf_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

lime_basil_seeds.name: Lime Basil
lime_basil_seeds.short_descr: Just like in its name, the Lime Basil produces leaves that are bright green and have a very unique lime scent and flavor. This unusual basil is a very good for a variety for its culinary uses.

little_cuba_tobacco_seed.name: Little Cuba Tobacco
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Little Cuba is a small bush like plant that matures very early. Blooms first appear in 28 days. Clipping the blooms will encourage more growth from below and 3-4 new branches will grow up to 3'-4' high. This will increase the yield of this small Cuban type tobacco and a second bloom will appear at about 60 days. The leaves are between 7"-10" in width and 10"-14" long. Leaves appearing before the first bloom will ripen first becoming a mottled yellow with yellow edges.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
little_cuba_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

magnolia_tobacco_seed.name: Magnolia Tobacco
magnolia_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Magnolia is a cigar wrapper which produces a high quality oval shaped leaf averaging 16" wide by 20" to 24" long. It grows to 8' in height, maturing in 65-70 days and produces 24-26 harvestable leaves. It has little to no suckering before topping. The leaves turn a lighter green with yellowing tips and mottling when ripe. Magnolia is very similar to Moonlight, but  it produces 2-3 less leaves per plant and matures 7-10 days earlier.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
magnolia_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.name: Mammoth Long Island Dill
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.short_descr: The Mammoth Long Island Dill is an attractive, tall, large-sized dill variety that has a lovely, tangy aroma that is perfect as a pickling spice. The leaves, immature flower tops and mature seeds are all used as an essential pickling spice. This easy-to-grow productive herb will reseed itself if allowed. As a companion plant, the Mammoth Long Island Dill can enhance the growth of cabbages, onions, lettuce and tomatoes.
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.before_planting: Dill grows best sown directly into the garden in the early spring after the last frost. To ensure a continuous harvest, plant dill seeds every 10 days up until the early summer. Dill also can be planted in containers, like most herbs, but a deep pot should be used to accommodate for the herb’s deep roots.
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.planting: Plant seeds ¼ inch deep and 18 inches apart.
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.watering: Water regularly. Be careful not to over-water and allow the soil to go dry between watering
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.fertilizer: Similar to most herbs dill does not require fertilizing to grow. In the late spring, a light feeding of a 5-10-5 fertilizer will encourage the dill to grow without being overbearing. If dill is grown in a container, use a liquid fertilizer but only use half of the label’s recommended strength. Fertilize container dill every four to six weeks.
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.days_to_maturity: Dill is ready to harvest any time before its yellow, umbrella-like flowers begin to open. (See each variety for days to maturity)
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.harvesting: Once dill is ready to harvest, you can snip individual stems or pull up the entire plant. To save the dill seeds, cut the dill four inches below the flower head once seeds begin to turn brown. Hang the clippings upside
mammoth_long_island_dill_seed.tips: Since dill can grow so tall, shelter it from wind or add a stake to the stem to support the plant as it grows higher.

mason_jar_herb_kits.name: Mason Jar Herb Kits
mason_jar_herb_kits.short_descr:
Everything you need to grow a custom mason jar herb kit at any time of the year!
			Includes: 3 mason jars (pint), organic soil, rocks, label, twine, and seeds.
			Comes with 5 herb packets (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley). This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family.
			Herb kit comes with porous rocks at bottom to help with drainage. Do not over water your plants.
			Jar Dimensions: 4"x 4"x 6" (16 Ounce)

metal_herb_garden_kit_round_garden_gifts.name: Metal Herb Garden Kit (Round) Garden Gifts
metal_herb_garden_kit_round_garden_gifts.short_descr:
Everything you need to grow a custom herb kit at any time of the year! This herb kit comes with three galvanized steel pots and tray stand that will last for years! Comes with 5 herb packets (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley). This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family.
			Includes: 3 Metal Pots, 1 Drip Tray, Soil Pellets, Herb Seeds, Wooden Markers and Instructions. Dimensions: 14"x 4"x 4"

metal_herb_kit_square_herb_kit.name: Metal Herb Kit (Square) Herb Kit
metal_herb_kit_square_herb_kit.short_descr:
Everything you need to grow a custom herb kit at any time of the year! This herb kit comes with three galvanized steel pots and tray stand that will last for years! Comes with 5 herb packets (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, parsley). This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family.
			Includes: 3 Metal Pots, 1 Drip Tray, Soil Pellets, Herb Seeds, Wooden Markers and Instructions. Dimensions: 14"x 4"x 4"

metal_herb_kit_with_handle_herb_kits.name: Metal Herb Kit with Handle Herb Kits
metal_herb_kit_with_handle_herb_kits.short_descr: Everything you need to grow a custom herb kit at any time of the year! This herb kit comes with three galvanized steel pots with handles! Comes with herb seeds (basil, cilantro, rosemary, chives, oregano), soil, wooden plant markers and planting instructions. This herb kit will grow great indoors and out! It looks great on a windowsill and will provide tasty fresh herbs for your family. Herb garden kit measures 14"x4"x5".

mohawk_tobacco_seed.name: Mohawk Tobacco
mohawk_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Mohawk Rustica is native to Central America as was widely cultivated by Native Americans and grown through out the southern US. It grows to 3' in height and is similar to Aztec, but with less branching. The leaves are thick, dark green in color and are among the largest of any Rustica variety. The flowers are a bright yellow and are densely packed. Mohawk is very high in nicotine content.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
mohawk_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

mrs_burns_basil_seeds.name: Mrs Burns Basil
mrs_burns_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Mrs. Burns Basil is a customer favorite that is known for its deliciously sweet and tangy lemon-lime flavor and scent! This popular basil variety has many wonderful culinary uses. The Mrs. Burns blooms pinky blooms that add a beautiful pop of color.

munstead_lavender_seeds.name: Munstead Lavender
munstead_lavender_seeds.short_descr: The Munstead Lavender is a beautifully mounded, bushy lavender plant variety that gives off a very delicate, sweet aroma. This bushy variety produces very attractive fragrant, purple flowers that are perfect for adding to bouquets or garnished on baked goods.
munstead_lavender_seeds.before_planting: Lavender should be planted outside after the last spring frost. You can also begin lavender inside and once the plants have their first set of leaves, transplant them to their final spot outdoors. However, if beginning inside, use a vermiculite mix instead of traditional potting mix to allow for better drainage.
munstead_lavender_seeds.planting: When transplanting, space plants 12 inches apart in rows set 12 inches apart. Lavender also can grow in containers. If growing in a container, use a porous soil and don’t over-water.
munstead_lavender_seeds.watering: Lavender thrives in hot weather, so be careful not to over-water as sodden soil can damage the plants.
munstead_lavender_seeds.fertilizer: Lavender plants typically grow best in soil with poor nutrients. Over-fertilizing the plant can cause an excess in leaves and limited fragrant flowers. A more natural way to fertilize lavender is by placing an inch of compost around the plant. Do not fertilize the plant in the fall, as this will encourage new growth that will then be killed by the winter months.
munstead_lavender_seeds.days_to_maturity: Once the herb begins to bloom, remove the faded flowers to encourage more growth. Lavender is a perennial in some zones, so cut the dead branches back in the spring to prepare for the new season. (See each variety for days to maturity)
munstead_lavender_seeds.harvesting: If using lavender as a bouquet, harvest it before the buds have fully opened. Partially closed buds will keep their scent and color longer.
munstead_lavender_seeds.tips: Add sand or limestone gravel to a bed to improve its drainage or plant the lavender in raised beds.

negro_black_tobacco_seed.name: Negro Black Tobacco
negro_black_tobacco_seed.short_descr:
Negro Black   Also called  "Tabaco Negro" in Spanish, is a name for dark tobacco that is dark in color and strong in taste. Black or dark tobacco is primarily used in cigars and dark cigarettes. It is often slowly darkened by a long curing and fermenting process to give a dark brown to black tobacco with exceptionally mild smoking characteristics.
 
Negro Black grows 5' to 6' in height with a classic Virginian type plant form and leaf shape. The leaves are a medium to dark green averaging 12" to 14" in width and 20" to 22" in length. It matures in 55-60 days.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
negro_black_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.name: Paris Wrapper Tobacco
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.short_descr: The Paris Wrapper Tobacco variety is a great choice for a cigar wrapper, binder or cigarette tobacco as well as an ornamental tobacco. This tobacco is an heirloom bright leaf variety that is a vigorous early season grower reaching a height of 6 feet. Its leaves grow to 30" long and 20" wide. Paris Wrapper's leaves are a very light green with white stems.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
paris_wrapper_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

peppermint_mint_seeds.name: Peppermint Mint
peppermint_mint_seeds.short_descr: The Peppermint has excellent leaves with a refreshing aromatic smell. Peppermint leaves are used as flavoring in baking, such as peppermint candies and teas. These plants are the perfect addition to any garden and can reach 3 feet tall.

persian_basil_seeds.name: Persian Basil
persian_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Persian Basil produces beautifully large and amazingly delicious bright green leaves that will enhance just about any dish! You will love having this beauty grow in your garden and so will pollinators as it is also a very attractive ornamental plant. Enjoy the zesty Persian Basil in any soup, pasta or salad. This variety is a prolific producer.
persian_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
persian_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
persian_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
persian_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
persian_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
persian_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
persian_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

pistou_basil_seeds.name: Pistou Basil
pistou_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Pistou Basil is a very petite variety with an excellent spicy taste that is delicious as a garnish or made into a sauce. This basil variety produces uniform mid-size, dense green leaves, perfect for growing in small pots. This small, compact plant has a nice, beautiful round body.
pistou_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
pistou_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
pistou_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
pistou_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
pistou_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
pistou_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
pistou_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.name: Plain Leaf Chervil
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.short_descr: The Plain Leaf Chervil resembles Italian parsley in appearance, but has a stronger, sweeter flavor that is often paired with tarragon, chives and parsley. This Brussels winter type is a vigorous plant with a subtle warm flavor that is excellent in fish and chicken dishes or light sauces and dressings.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.before_planting: Chervil should be sown directly outdoors in the spring or fall. If planting in the spring, sow outdoors about two weeks before the last frost. Chervil seeds will not germinate well if they are older than one year.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.planting: To plant, sow a group of five seeds just below the surface of the soil and space each grouping 12 inches apart. Firmly press on the soil over the seeds and keep the area well-watered. The chervil plant makes for a great indoor herb, as it is not a fan of hot conditions.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.watering: Since chervil does not grow well in hot conditions, water the plant consistently.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.fertilizer: To encourage more leaves, add a nitrogen-rich fertilizer to the chervil plants. Since most herbs don’t require fertilization, take care not to over-fertilize the plants.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Chervil leaves are ready to harvest about six weeks after planting, and gardeners can harvest them as needed.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.harvesting: Pick the leaves from the outside of the plant first, as those will have the best flavor. To harvest the leaves, just pinch them off with your fingers. Chervil can tolerate some frost, but once cold weather is consistent, harvest as much chervil as possible before the plant dies.
plain_leaf_chervil_seeds.tips: Since chervil is an annual, reseed the plant so it returns the following year. To do so, after harvesting for the season, replant the chervil with seeds from the seed heads after you cleared the dead stalks out of the herb bed.

plant_in_a_bag_herb_kits.name: Plant in a Bag Herb Kits
plant_in_a_bag_herb_kits.short_descr: Easy and fun to grow plants in a bag! These easy to grow kits are perfect for a windowsill or sunny location. Great for someone who loves to cook using fresh herbs and vegetables. The 'Plant in a Bag' comes with everything you need to get started. Just add water and watch the plant take off. A great gift for a gardener, cook, or anyone with a sunny window!

purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.name: Purple Ruffles Basil
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Purple Ruffles Basil is a large, heavily ruffled and fringed dark purple leaf variety with beautiful pink-purple flowers. This All-American Selections winner basil is the perfect pop of color for herb gardens or a flower border. This basil produces a sweet fragrance and flavor that is wonderful as a garnish in salads, soups, pasta or drinks.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
purple_ruffles_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

red_rubin_basil_seeds.name: Red Rubin Basil
red_rubin_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Red Rubin Basil is a reliable, popular red basil variety that produces beautiful dark red leaves that are perfect for home gardens! These dark red leaves have a great flavor and aroma. The Red Rubin is a wonderful variety for adding color to salads and meals.

shirey_tobacco_seed.name: Shirey Tobacco
shirey_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Shirey is a dark Virginian type tobacco with a mild flavor but with a fuller richer flavor than Virginia Golds have. It is an an excellent tobacco for a cigarette or pipe blend. It produces a large leaf that air cures easily to a medium brown. It is a hardy plant and with stands moderate late season frosts. Grows to a height of 5 1/2 to 6 feet and matures in 65 days.
shirey_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
shirey_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
shirey_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
shirey_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
shirey_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
shirey_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

siam_queen_basil_seeds.name: Siam Queen Basil
siam_queen_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Siam Queen Basil is a newer variety of basil that is perfect for adding into any Thai cuisine, especially fish and beef dishes! This variety's young shoots are perfect for a continual harvest throughout the whole season.

slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.name: Slow Bolt Cilantro
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.short_descr:
The Slow Bolt Cilantro is an easy to grow variety that has a great flavor! This variety gets its name for being slow to bolt; bolting means that the plant starts to produce the seed, rather than growing more leaves. This cilantro is a pungent member of the carrot family that is a favored ingredient for Asian and Latin American cuisine, including salsa and other Mexican dishes. The Slow Bolt Cilantro's mature, spicy dried seeds, coriander, are a staple of Indian cooking.
          
           Organic seed available.
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.before_planting: Prior to planting the seeds, you must prepare them so they will be able to germinate. Coriander seeds are actually two seeds encased in a husk. Crush the husk gently by holding the two seeds together and then soak the seeds in water for 24 to 48 hours. Remove the seeds from the water and allow them to dry prior to planting.
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.planting: Cilantro can be started indoors or outdoors. Plant the seeds ¼ inch deep. To transplant a cilantro plant
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.watering: Water regularly, but be careful not to over-water the plant as it could create yellow leaves. To prevent leaf spot, make sure the plant is in well-drained soil.
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.fertilizer: During its first few weeks of life, cilantro grows well if a water-soluble fertilizer is applied. Fertilize with a
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.days_to_maturity: Cilantro is ready to harvest within 45 days.
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.harvesting: Cut the upper new leaves to harvest. Unlike other herbs, cilantro is rarely frozen and used later in cooking as it loses almost all of its scent and flavor if not fresh.
slow_bolt_cilantro_seeds.tips: Cilantro likes full sun, but in hotter climates, partial shade will be tolerated as the plant bolts in warm weather.

slow_bolt_organic_cilantro_seeds.name: Slow Bolt Organic Cilantro
slow_bolt_organic_cilantro_seeds.short_descr:
(Organic Seed) The Slow Bolt Cilantro is an easy to grow variety that has a great flavor! This variety gets its name for being slow to bolt; bolting means that the plant starts to produce the seed, rather than growing more leaves. This cilantro is a pungent member of the carrot family that is a favored ingredient for Asian and Latin American cuisine, including salsa and other Mexican dishes. The Slow Bolt Cilantro's mature, spicy dried seeds, coriander, are a staple of Indian cooking.
          
           Conventional seed available.

Crush the husk gently by holding the two seeds together and then soak the seeds in water for 24 to 48 hours. Remove the seeds from the water and allow them to dry prior to planting.

slow_bolt_organic_cilantro_seeds.tips: Cilantro likes full sun, but in hotter climates, partial shade will be tolerated as the plant bolts in warm weather.

spearmint_mint_seed.name: Spearmint Mint
spearmint_mint_seed.short_descr: The cool, refreshing scent of Spearmint is one that cannot be resisted! This perennial can spread up to 3 feet. Spearmint has many culinary and medicinal uses and is great for making teas, sauces, jellies, sweets, and garnishes as well as curing a stomach ache.

spicy_bush_basil_seeds.name: Spicy Bush Basil
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Spicy Bush Basil is a very bushy basil variety that produces tiny, bright green leaves that have a big spicy, sweet punch! This variety's small green plants resemble compact boxwood bushes with a beautiful round top.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
spicy_bush_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

standard_organic_chive_seeds.name: Standard Organic Chive
standard_organic_chive_seeds.short_descr: The Standard Chive is a hardy perennial herb that is equally attractive as it is delicious. The 6-12 inch tall clumps are perfect for patio containers! Along with the delicate, flat onion-flavored leaves, the standard chives is also popular for the cut and come again lavender flowers. This organic favorite is widely used as flavoring in many dishes.

sweet_genovese_organic_basil_seeds.name: Sweet Genovese Organic Basil
sweet_genovese_organic_basil_seeds.short_descr:
The Sweet Genovese Basil is a popular Italian variety that is prized for its large leaves, wonderful aroma and spicy flavor. If you are making pesto, than this is the basil for you! This basil variety's plants will grow to be 18-24” tall. Make successive sowings for a steady supply and make sure to dry or freeze some for winter use!
          
           Certified Organic
          
          .
          
           Learn more about our organic seeds.
sweet_genovese_organic_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
sweet_genovese_organic_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.

Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.

sweet_high_oil_organic_basil_seeds.name: Sweet High Oil Organic Basil
sweet_high_oil_organic_basil_seeds.short_descr:
The Sweet High Oil Basil has beautiful leaves that have a wonderful sweet flavor, making it perfect for pestos, sauces and salads! This organic heirloom basil is great for an outdoor or indoor herb garden. The large leaves of the Sweet High Oil can be used fresh or dried. Enjoy the sun-loving Sweet High Oil year after year!
          
           Certified Organic
          
          .
          
           Learn more about our organic seeds.

sweet_marjoram_seed.name: Sweet Marjoram
sweet_marjoram_seed.short_descr: The delicious aroma of the Sweet Marjoram is similar to oregano or thyme, but has a sweeter fragrance that adds a mild and fresh taste to different dishes. This variety is a compact plant with beautiful, edible flowers, which have a mild and marjoram-like flavor, and can be used to garnish salads, soups, stews, sauces, and stuffing. Both the leaves and flowers of the Sweet Marjoram pairs well with citrus, mushrooms and fish.
sweet_marjoram_seed.before_planting: Marjoram should be planted outdoors when there is no longer any threat of frost, but it is a slow-growing plant so seeds should be started indoors first. Begin seeds indoors as
sweet_marjoram_seed.planting: Distribute seeds evenly on the surface of wet soil but do not bury them. When transplanting seedlings outside, plant them at least 12 inches apart. Marjoram can grow up to 2 to 3 feet wide.
sweet_marjoram_seed.watering: Water regularly, but do not over-water. Allow the soil to go almost completely dry between watering.
sweet_marjoram_seed.fertilizer: Marjoram doesn’t require much fertilizer, but upon transplanting the herb to the garden, a granular plant food can be added to the soil. A slow-release fertilizer can be added to soil prior to planting or compost can be added to the soil as well.
sweet_marjoram_seed.days_to_maturity: Marjoram is ready to harvest just before its flowers are open, generally six weeks after planting and once it is at least 3 feet tall. (See variety for days to harvest)
sweet_marjoram_seed.harvesting: If marjoram is harvested when its blooms are fully open, there is a bitter taste. Never harvest more than a third of marjoram’s leaves at a time. After harvesting the marjoram, bundle the cuttings and hang them upside down to dry to use as dried herbs.
sweet_marjoram_seed.tips: Marjoram is good at repelling cabbage moths from the garden and can be planted in between rows of Brassica plants to prevent moths from ruining them. Marjoram also grows well if planted near asparagus and basil.

thai_basil_seeds.name: Thai Basil
thai_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Thai Basil is a highly ornamental and fragrant variety that produces deep green leaves with beautiful purple stems and blossoms. This variety has a distinctive flavor combination of cloves and mint with a delicate sweetness. You can use both its leaves and flowers in recipes as well as a garnish.

triple_curled_parsley_seed.name: Triple Curled Parsley
triple_curled_parsley_seed.short_descr: The Triple Curled Parsley has beautifully intense triple curled leaves with dark green stems that look great as a garnish. This is a popular variety that is easy to grow, clean and harvest.
triple_curled_parsley_seed.before_planting: Like most herbs, parsley can be grown indoors, in a container or in the garden. To encourage parsley to have a better germination, soak the seeds in water overnight.
triple_curled_parsley_seed.planting: Parsley seeds can be sown directly into the garden as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring, but they also can be started indoors six weeks before moving out to the garden since parsley has a slow germination
triple_curled_parsley_seed.watering: Parsley requires little maintenance and only needs watering once per week.
triple_curled_parsley_seed.fertilizer: If growing parsley in the ground, parsley does best with a single application of fertilizer halfway through the growing season with a 5-10-5 fertilizer. Growing parsley in pots calls for more fertilizer, so apply fertilizer every six weeks for pots indoors and every four weeks if grown in pots outdoors.
triple_curled_parsley_seed.days_to_maturity: Once parsley leaves begin to curl or when the leaves have three separate segments, they are ready to harvest. (See each variety for days to harvest)
triple_curled_parsley_seed.harvesting: Pick parsley leaves early in the morning as that is when the herb’s scent is the strongest. To harvest parsley, cut the leaves from the outer part of the plant first. To store fresh parsley, snip entire stems and keep the stems immersed in water in the refrigerator.
triple_curled_parsley_seed.tips: Parsley is mostly disease resistant, though it can be a victim to aphids.

true_comfrey_seed.name: True Comfrey
true_comfrey_seed.short_descr: Comfrey is a hardy, drought tolerant plant that is easy to start from seed. A clumping herb comprised of multiple stalks, prefers well drained soil and full sun to partial shade. Grows between 36-48 inches. Comfrey will put nutrients into the soil, mulch trees, and shrubs, prevent weeds, feed livestock, attract beneficial pollinators, and make quick compost tea.

valentino_basil_seeds.name: Valentino Basil
valentino_basil_seeds.short_descr: The Valentino Basil is a tasty and fragrant, large leaf basil variety that is perfect for adding into sauces and dressings. This basil plant can reach 15" inches high and 10" inches wide.
valentino_basil_seeds.before_planting: Basil grows best in warm weather, and basil seeds should be planted after all dangers of frost have passed.
valentino_basil_seeds.planting: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and 12 inches apart. Seeds can be started indoors to get a head start on growing the herb. Plant indoors six weeks before the last frost date and place in a sunny windowsill. Plant in moist soil that is well-drained. If planting in a container, use a larger pot to prevent plants from drying out in the summer heat.
valentino_basil_seeds.watering: Water Basil frequently during dry periods.
valentino_basil_seeds.fertilizer: Upon planting, add organic nutrients to the soil such as compost, blood meal or cottonseed meal. Feed with liquid plant food every few weeks to encourage growth, but be sure to not use fertilizers that leave a harmful residue since you will be consuming the leaves.
valentino_basil_seeds.days_to_maturity: Basil leaves can begin to be harvested once the plant is 6 to 8 inches tall, typically 60 to 90 days after planting the seeds.
valentino_basil_seeds.harvesting: Picking leaves regularly encourages more growth. Harvest the leaves by pinching them off of the stem, and always harvest from the top of the plant. Basil can be frozen to preserve its flavor, used fresh or dried.
valentino_basil_seeds.tips: The biggest threat to a basil plant is root rot from poor drainage, so ensure the planting site has adequate drainage. Also, watch out for pests such as aphids, slugs or Japanese beetles.

vera_lavender_seed.name: Vera Lavender
vera_lavender_seed.short_descr: The Vera Lavender is a very popular home garden lavender variety that produces a lovely, strong lavender scent that can be used to freshen up the home. This lavender variety has several uses including both culinary and medicinal properties. The Vera lavender plants grow to be 18" to 36" tall and produces a profusion of lilac-purple flowers on silvery foliage.
vera_lavender_seed.before_planting: Lavender should be planted outside after the last spring frost. You can also begin lavender inside and once the plants have their first set of leaves, transplant them to their final spot outdoors. However, if beginning inside, use a vermiculite mix instead of traditional potting mix to allow for better drainage.
vera_lavender_seed.planting: When transplanting, space plants 12 inches apart in rows set 12 inches apart. Lavender also can grow in containers. If growing in a container, use a porous soil and don’t over-water.
vera_lavender_seed.watering: Lavender thrives in hot weather, so be careful not to over-water as sodden soil can damage the plants.
vera_lavender_seed.fertilizer: Lavender plants typically grow best in soil with poor nutrients. Over-fertilizing the plant can cause an excess in leaves and limited fragrant flowers. A more natural way to fertilize lavender is by placing an inch of compost around the plant. Do not fertilize the plant in the fall, as this will encourage new growth that will then be killed by the winter months.
vera_lavender_seed.days_to_maturity: Once the herb begins to bloom, remove the faded flowers to encourage more growth. Lavender is a perennial in some zones, so cut the dead branches back in the spring to prepare for the new season. (See each variety for days to maturity)
vera_lavender_seed.harvesting: If using lavender as a bouquet, harvest it before the buds have fully opened. Partially closed buds will keep their scent and color longer.
vera_lavender_seed.tips: Add sand or limestone gravel to a bed to improve its drainage or plant the lavender in raised beds.

virginia_116_tobacco_seed.name: Virginia 116 Tobacco
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Virginia 116 is a bright leaf Virginia Gold variety which grows to 4 1/2 feet in height. Good disease resistance. It produces an average of 19 leaves when topped, excluding bed leaves. Leaves are up to 24" long and 12" wide. It gives good yields, and turns light yellow as it ripens in around 65 days. Easy to air cure and dries a bright golden yellow. It is mild to smoke and is an excellent choice for a cigarette tobacco or in a pipe.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
virginia_116_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.name: Virginia 15 Tobacco
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.short_descr: Virginia 15 is a light, aromatic cigarette and pipe tobacco. The plant grows to an average of 5' in height producing 22 leaves per plant. Leaves average 14" wide and up to 20" to 22" in length. It is a low nicotine variety with dried leaf averaging 0.95%. It is resistant to most diseases. Virginia 15 is a late maturing variety reaching bloom at 90-95 days.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
virginia_15_tobacco_seeds.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.name: Virginia Bright Leaf Tobacco
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Virginia Bright Leaf is an heirloom variety dating back many decades. It averages 6' in height with 18-20 leaves per plant below the crows foot. It reaches maturity when blooms appear at 55 days. The light green leaves average 12" wide by 24" long and become a light yellow/green when ripe. Leaves began to ripen as the plant reaches bloom. Air cures easily to a light golden brown with yields averaging 3 oz of dried leaf per plant.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
virginia_bright_leaf_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.name: Virginia Gold Tobacco
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.short_descr: Virginia Gold is a well known heirloom variety dating back well over 50 years. It grows to a height of 6'-7' with low suckering. The light green leaves are from 14" to 18" wide and 24" to 30" long, and turn a light yellow when ripe. The plants produce an average of 18 leaves per plant below the crows foot, with yields averaging 3 oz of dried leaf per plant. Matures in 55 days.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.before_planting: The tobacco seed is very small, so it must be started indoors. Tobacco prefers soil with a pH of 5.8 and well-drained soils.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.planting: Begin the seed in seed compost and not potting mix six weeks before the last frost. When planting, place the seed on top of the compost and do not cover it. In addition to warmer temps, it also requires light to germinate. Seedlings are ready to be transplanted once they reach 8 inches in height. Transplant them after all dangers of frost have passed.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.watering: Water 1/2 inch weekly, but be careful because over0watering can make the plants become thin and flaky.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.fertilizer: To fertilize tobacco, use the same fertilizers used for tomatoes or peppers. Fertilizer should contain no chlorine and its nitrogen should be in nitrate form. Apply the fertilizer over several separate instances, such as applying it to the soil before transplanting and continuously throughout the tobacco’s growing season to keep the leaves a solid green color. Once flowers begin to form, stop the fertilization process.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.days_to_maturity: Tobacco plants can be harvested around 60 days after being transplanted.
virginia_gold_tobacco_seed.harvesting: Tobacco plants can be harvested by cutting down the entire plant at once or by pulling individual leaves from the plant.

vulgaris_thyme_seed.name: Vulgaris Thyme
vulgaris_thyme_seed.short_descr: The Vulgaris Thyme, or also known as German Winter Thyme, is a Mediterranean herb with culinary, medicinal and ornamental uses. This thyme variety has larger leaves and is a great herb to add flavor to many fish, chicken and vegetable dishes. The Vulgaris plant produces well and is more frost hardy than other thyme varieties.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.before_planting: Thyme grows very slowly from seed and after planting, germination can take up to 28 days.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.planting: If planting from seed, begin thyme indoors and scatter the seeds on top of the soil and do not cover them or only cover them lightly. If growing thyme in containers, repot the thyme every season, as its roots may begin to grow out the bottom of the container.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.watering: Thyme doesn’t require much care. Allow soil to completely dry in between watering.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.fertilizer: Upon planting, add a continuous-release fertilizer to the soil. Add the fertilizer again each spring. Other fertilization options include fertilizing thyme with fish emulsion or liquid seaweed every two weeks but dilute the fertilizer by half.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.days_to_maturity: Harvest thyme before its flowers open which should be after 85 days.
vulgaris_thyme_seed.harvesting: Harvest by cutting the plant 2 inches from the ground. After the first cut is made, more growth will begin to develop but do not harvest this second growth as the new growth increases the plant’s hardiness over
vulgaris_thyme_seed.tips: Stop harvest a month before the first fall frost to ensure the plants are strong enough for the winter. After harvesting, lay the thyme in single layers on newspaper in the shade. Once dry, rub the leaves and they will separate easily from the stems.

white_sage_seed.name: White Sage
white_sage_seed.short_descr: Vary aromatic and white-green leaves. White sage has many herbal uses.
white_sage_seed.planting: Plant the seeds or cuttings indoors up to 10 weeks before the last frost. Plant outdoors up to two weeks before the last frost and leave 30 inches between the seeds or cuttings when planting. Sage does well when planted near cabbage, carrots and rosemary, but do not plant sage near cucumbers.
white_sage_seed.watering: When sage plants are young, water them frequently to prevent them from drying out.
white_sage_seed.fertilizer: Twice during its growing season, side dress the plant with compost or a compost tea, especially if the plant is grown in a container. This replaces the nutrients in the soil. Sage doesn’t require any other fertilizer.
white_sage_seed.days_to_maturity: Once the leaves are full size, they are able to be pulled off. (See variety for days to maturity)
white_sage_seed.harvesting: To harvest individual leaves, pull them off by hand. Entire stems also can be cut, and they should be snipped at their base. Sage can be harvested in its first year but harvest lightly so the plant grows back completely
white_sage_seed.tips: Each spring, prune back the woody stems. For the best quality of sage, replace the plants every five years as it begins to become woodier the older the plant gets.

wild_bergamot_monarda_seeds.name: Wild Bergamot Monarda
wild_bergamot_monarda_seeds.short_descr: The Wild Bergamot Monarda is the best bee balm for dry locations and produces beautiful violet blooms that have a wonderful scent! This variety has great mid-summer blooms, later than any other Monardas. The Wild Bergamot will attract a large amount of butterflies, bees and hummingbirds!
